newsitem.title: USA: US Treasury mulls 5-yr inflation-protected notes.
newsitem.headline: US Treasury mulls 5-yr inflation-protected notes.

text.p: While the U.S. Treasury has not yet decided what maturity it will offer at either of its two inflation-protected securities auctions in the second half of the year, a five-year issue is getting consideration, suggested Roger Anderson, Treasury's Deputy Assistant Secretary of Federal Finance.

Anderson, in an interview with Reuters, reiterated that there will be a second mauturity offered at Treasury's quarterly index-lined bond auctions in July and October, but whether it will be longer or shorter than a 10-year note was not yet decided.
"Over the long run, we're going to set aside both interests," Anderson said.
A third maturity will be offered in 1998, he said.
Anderson noted that it's possible the 10-year index-linked note could be re-opened again later in the year, but the Treasury is also looking at a five-year note and 30-year bond.

"A lot of market people have said there is substantial interest in the five-year sector," Anderson said. "A lot of the corporate issuance that has been done are fairly short. A lot of them have been five-years and one of them was even three years.
"There's more retail interest in the shorter end and therefore there is more mutual fund interest," he added.
Wednesday, Treasury announced it will sell $8 billion of 10-year inflation-indexed notes on April 8, in a reopening of the note sold in late January.

Anderson said the re-opening was to build up the size of the issue and give it more liquidity. "We have talked to a lot of market participants before we made a decision and almost all of them recomended a reopening," he said.
As for whether the eventual longer-term offering will be a 20-year or 30-year bond, Anderson said that most market participants prefer a 30-year, but no decision has been made yet.

Anderson also noted the 10-year index-linked bond has traded quite well the past six weeks. Since mid-February, the nominal 10-year note has gained 58 basis points in yield (to 6.86 percent from 6.28 percent), whereas its index-linked companion was up only about 33 basis points (to 3.58 percent).
"It is a little early to read a whole lot of meaning into these numbers," Anderson said. "But they are interesting."
